thread.title: UPS launching Saturday ground delivery in major metropolitan markets
thread.title_full: UPS launching Saturday ground delivery in major metropolitan markets

author: USA TODAY
title: UPS launching Saturday ground delivery in major metropolitan markets
text:
Let friends in your social network know what you are reading about Facebook Email UPS launching Saturday ground delivery in major metropolitan markets The company said it would pick up and deliver packages by ground on Saturdays. Post to Facebook UPS launching Saturday ground delivery in major metropolitan markets The company said it would pick up and deliver packages by ground on Saturdays. Check out this story on USATODAY.com: http://usat.ly/2lv06jp Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Join the Nation's Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs UPS launching Saturday ground delivery in major metropolitan markets Nathan Bomey , USA TODAY Published 9:31   7 minutes ago United Parcel Service will hire 95,000 employees for this holiday season. (Photo: David Goldman, AP) CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Shipping service UPS plans to begin accepting and delivering U.S. packages by ground on Saturdays in certain markets. 
The move will allow customers in some cases to ship packages on Saturday for delivery Monday. Competitors FedEx and the U.S. Postal Service offer similar services. 
UPS made the announcement at the company's investor conference Tuesday in New York City. The new service is already rolling out in the "largest metropolitan areas," UPS said. 
UPS U.S. operations president Myron Gray told investors that the Saturday ground service will reach more than 50% of U.S. residents in 2017. "We'll add more in 2018," Gray said. 
The move is also expected to "free up more ground capacity during the first half of the week," CEO David Abney told investors Tuesday, according to a transcript. "That expands our delivery capacity with no incremental capital investment. It also maintains the flexibility to take advantage of new opportunities that come our way." 
The Saturday delivery expansion will add an additional $100 million to $200 million in annual operating costs. 
The company also announced that it was testing delivery of packages from a truck-launched drone . 
Meanwhile, UPS also told investors Tuesday that about 40% of "eligible" U.S. packages currently flow through sites with "high" levels of automation. That will transition to "every" site by 2021 as automation presents a significant cost savings opportunity. 
Follow USA TODAY reporter Nathan Bomey on Twitter @ NathanBomey .
